conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves backward.
A cylindrical container casting shadow A.
A green avocado casting shadow B.
An unknown object casting shadow C.
A waffle or waffle-like food item casting shadow D.
The cement/concrete surface has a crack running across it, and the objects are sitting on this surface.
Shadows become less defined/more diffuse when the light source moves farther away while remaining directly above objects.
Shadows become smaller when the light source moves farther away while remaining directly above objects.
Shadows' positions shift closer to being directly beneath their respective objects when the light source moves farther away while remaining directly above objects.
Shadow A will become smaller when the light moves backward.
Shadow A will move closer to being directly beneath the container when the light moves backward.
Shadow A edges will become less defined when the light moves backward.
Shadow B will become smaller when the light moves backward.
Shadow B will move closer to being directly beneath the avocado when the light moves backward.
Shadow B will become less defined when the light moves backward.
Shadow C will become smaller when the light moves backward.
Shadow C will move closer to being directly beneath its source object when the light moves backward.
Shadow C will become less defined when the light moves backward.
Shadow D will become smaller when the light moves backward.
Shadow D will move closer to being directly beneath the waffle when the light moves backward.
Shadow D will become less defined when the light moves backward.
Light rays become more parallel to each other when a light source moves farther away.
A light source creates a less harsh shadow (more diffuse) when it's farther away.
All shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become smaller in size when the light source moves backward while remaining above the objects.
